data.title: Every single Nike & Puma shirt worn by Arsenal ahead of mega adidas deal for the 2019/20 season
data.meta_description: The club signed a huge deal with adidas back in October
data.text:
Home 1994/96

Nike made quite a few changes to the Arsenal home shirt after taking over from adidas at the start of the 1994 season.

Opting for a white shirt collar and a zigzag pattern on the shirt, the American company elected against using the blue trim on the previous home design, as well as reducing the amount of white on the sleeves.

Worn by: Tony Adams, Ian Wright, John Jensen.

Away 1994/95

Arsenal's first Nike away shirt was rather different with the club tending to go for a yellow change strip.

The navy and turquoise kit was based on the club's home design and had the same zigzag pattern and hooped socks.

Worn by: Lee Dixon, Ray Parlour, Glenn Helder.

Third 1994/96

Nike also introduced a third shirt for the 1994/95 season but it was only ever worn twice.

Worn for the very first time against Liverpool in the Coca-Cola Cup that campaign, the shirt actually wasn't made available to buy.

The yellow jersey once again followed exactly the same design as the club's home and away shirts, although it was worn with the away shorts and socks.

Worn by: Paul Merson, Kevin Campbell, Alan Smith.

Away 1995/96

The Gunners had a rather striking away shirt for the 1995/96 season as they once again went with the navy and turquoise colours used in the previous campaign.

However, this time the shirt featured a rather bold version of the zig zag pattern that was used on the previous designs.

There was also a change on the shorts and socks as a large Gothic 'A' replaced the club crest.

Worn by: David Platt, Nigel Winterburn, Martin Keown.

Home 1996/98

One thing Nike changed for their second Arsenal home strip was the sleeves.

With only a little bit of white on their previous design, the American company went with all white sleeves ahead of the 1996 season.

The shirt also saw a change in the Nike logo with only the famous swoosh used.

Worn by: Dennis Bergkamp, Patrick Vieira, Christopher Wreh.

Away 1996/97

Arsenal's home shirt for the 1996/97 campaign replicated the home shirt but in yellow and navy blue.

Again using the Gothic 'A' on the shorts and socks instead of the club crest, the club went with rather plain socks instead of the previous hooped design.

Worn by: Stephan Hughes, Remi Garde, Andy Linighan.

Away 1997/99

Arsenal fans will remember the club's next away shirt from the famous 1-0 win over Manchester United at Old Trafford towards the end of the 1997/98 season.

Marc Overmars' goal proved crucial as the club went on to lift the Premier League title for the very first time.

The club's latest yellow away shirt was rather different as Nike went for varying sizes of navy bands on the chest and arms.

Instead of using the Gothic 'A' as Nike had done previously, they went for a cannon logo on the shorts.

Worn by: Nicolas Anelka, Matthew Upson, Gilles Grimandi.

Home 1998/00

Nike decided to shake things up for the club's next home design with navy blue making a comeback on the shirt.

Navy trim featured on the shirt and collar, with the same on the shorts and socks.

The Gunners had the home shirt for two seasons but the club's long partnership with JVC came to an end after the 1998/99 campaign with Dreamcast taking over.

Worn by: Emmanuel Petit, Freddie Ljungberg, Luis Boa Morte.

Third 1998/99

Arsenal needed a third shirt for the 1998/99 season with the club having a kit clash against RC Lens due to their red and yellow stripes.

Nike produced a navy top and it was only used the once as the team lost 1-0 in the Champions League at Wembley.

Just like the third shirt that was used between 1994 and 1996, it was never produced so fans could buy one.

Worn by: Steve Bould, Ray Parlour, Christopher Wreh.

Away 1999/01

The Gunners were once again decked out in a yellow change strip for the 1999/00 and 2000/01 seasons.

The shirt, which featured a unique V-neck, had navy blue on the bottom of the sleeves and down the side of the jersey.

It was the first Arsenal shirt to feature SEGA as the sponsor with Dreamcast featuring on the home kits.

Worn by: Thierry Henry, Sylvinho, Stefan Malz.

Home 2000/02

Nike ensured that navy remained on their next Arsenal home kit with piping running from the shoulders down the sleeves.

The design, which many will remember from their title triumph in 2002, also featured a red collar as opposed to the usual white one.

Worn by: Lauren, Edu, Robert Pires.

Third 2000/02

The Gunners were once again given a navy third kit that was almost identical to the 1998/99 shirt worn against RC Lens.

However, this one was slightly different as it featured yellow on the shirt and it was also worn with yellow socks.

Worn by: Lee Dixon, Oleg Luzhny, Nelson Vivas.

Away 2001/02

"WILTOOOOOOORRRD!"

One of the club's most iconic away shirts due to the famous 1-0 win over Manchester United in May 2002 that sealed the league title.

While some were unhappy with Nike moving away from the traditional yellow change shirt, everyone has fond memories of it due to that balmy night at Old Trafford.

Worn by: Sylvain Wiltord, Sol Campbell, Francis Jeffers.

Home 2002/04

A home shirt best remembered for the Invincibles after Arsene Wenger's side went through the 2003/04 season unbeaten in the league as they won the title.

There was no navy blue on this shirt as the Nike went with the club's traditional red body and white sleeves.

Worn by: Pascal Cygan, Gilberto Silva, Jermaine Pennant.

Away 2002/03

Nike once again went with another bold away kit for the 2002/03 season.

Using the same template as the home shirt, the top was predominantly navy but it had a rather striking light blue front.

Famously worn at Upton Park in August 2002 when Thierry Henry scored a breathtaking goal against West Ham.

Worn by: Ashley Cole, Kolo Toure, Giovanni van Bronckhorst.

Away 2003/04

Arsenal were back in yellow in 2003 with Nike opting to go for a rather bright design with blue collar and cuffs.

A shirt best known for Robert Pires' goal against Liverpool at Anfield and the club going the league season unbeaten.

Worn by: Jeremie Aliadiere, Gael Clichy, Jose Antonio Reyes.

Home 2004/05

A kit not too dissimilar to the previous home one, the design featured yellow piping on the body of the shirt and the socks.

Worn in the memorable win over Middlesbrough at the start of the 2004/05 season with the club's unbeaten record almost coming to a shock end.

Worn by: Cesc Fabregas, Robin van Persie, Mathieu Flamini.

Away 2004/05

The Gunners were back in navy after the eye-catching yellow shirt the previous season.

Based on the same template as the home shirt, the navy design also featured yellow piping on the front.

Worn by: Philippe Senderos, Patrick Vieira, Justin Hoyte.

Home 2005/06

Arsenal bid farewell to Highbury in 2006 as they got set to move to their new home only a short distance away.

Nike received plaudits after a launching a special redcurrant shirt as worn during the very first season at their famous home back in 1913.

Worn by: Emmanuel Adebayor, Alexander Hleb, Emmanuel Eboue.

Away 2005/07

Yellow made a return in 2005, although it wasn't as bright as their shirt from the 2003/04 season.

With O2 as the sponsor in the 2005/06 season, Fly Emirates were on the front the next campaign due to the club's mega deal with the company following their move from Highbury.

Worn by: Alex Song, Julio Baptista, Abou Diaby.

Home 2006/08

Arsenal were back in their traditional colours in 2006 with Nike producing a rather sleek design.

The red and white shirt was completed by gold piping running down the sides.

Worn by: Eduardo, Denilson, Johan Djourou.

Away 2007/08

The famous white shirt as worn by Cesc Fabregas when he found the net from distance against AC Milan in the Champions League in 2008.

The top was worn with burgundy shorts and hooped socks.

Worn by: Bacary Sagna, Lassana Diarra, William Gallas.

Third 2007/08

The Gunners also had a third kit for the 2007/08 season that proved very popular.

Nike did something different for Arsenal and went with a navy and burgundy hooped kit that was finished with gold trim.

Was worn in the Champions League defeat away against Sevilla and a Carling Cup quarter-final win away at Blackburn Rovers.

Worn by: Armand Traore, Gilberto Silva, Mark Randall.

Home 2008/10

One of the things that fans didn't like about the 2008/10 home shirt was the lack of white on the sleeves.

In a rather surprising move, Nike elected to go with predominantly red sleeves with only a bit of white on the top, while white also featured down the sides of the shirt.

Worn by: Mikael Silvestre, Samir Nasri, Nicklas Bendtner.

Away 2008/09

Worn during the famous 4-4 draw away at Liverpool in 2009 as Andrey Arshavin scored all of his side's goals.

It was the perfect yellow away shirt for many as it also had navy blue sleeves and shorts with a hint of red.

Worn by: Andrey Arshavin, Tomas Rosicky, Carlos Vela.

Away 2009/10

Arsene Wenger's side were back in a blue away shirt for the first time since the 2004/05 season with a rather smart design.

The navy shirt, which featured a collar for the first time in a few years, also had light blue pinstripes.

Worn by: Thomas Vermaelen, Theo Walcott, Kieran Gibbs.

Third 2009/10

The club's third kit for the 2009/10 was an exact replica of the away shirt but in white with dark grey shorts.

Fans will be remember it from the Champions League defeat against Barcelona at the Nou Camp.

Worn by: Sol Campbell, Fran Merida, Robin van Persie.

Home 2010/11

Nike made a couple of alterations to Arsenal's next home shirt with the club going back to their traditional white sleeves.

The shirt also featured a round collar in white, with the team also wearing plain white socks instead of having a hint of red on them.

Many will remember the 2010/11 home shirt from the incredible 4-4 draw against Newcastle United when the team somehow surrendered a four-goal lead.

Worn by: Marouane Chamakh, Sebastien Squillaci, Craig Eastmond.

Away 2010/11

The pinstripes from the previous away and third shirts remained as the Gunners returned to a yellow shirt.

Whereas previous yellow tops featured a more traditional blue, this had a burgundy collar and cuffs and the shorts were also the same colour.

Worn by: Laurent Koscielny, Jack Wilshere, Jay Emmanuel-Thomas.

Home 2011/12

The Gunners had a brand new home shirt the following season with the club celebrating their 125th anniversary.

The kit featured a bespoke crest but apart from that it was very similar to the previous design minus a couple of adjustments.

This was also the shirt worn by Thierry Henry as he marked his second debut for the club with a goal against Leeds United in the FA Cup.

Worn by: Per Mertesacker, Park Chu-young, Andre Santos.

Away 2011/12

A shirt best known for all the wrong reasons.

Whereas the gold shirt from the 2001/02 campaign will be remembered for securing the league title at Old Trafford, Arsenal's blue number ten years on will always bring back awful memories of the 8-2 drubbing against Manchester United.

Not the club's best away shirt, although certainly an improvement for many on the previous season's kit.

Worn by: Carl Jenkinson, Mikel Arteta, Thierry Henry.

Home 2012/14

The last Arsenal home shirt worn for more than one season.

Navy blue made a return to the shirt on the collar and cuffs, with the sleeves also featuring a red band.

It proved to be Nike's final home kit with the club signing a deal with Puma.

Worn by: Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain, Olivier Giroud, Lukas Podolski.

Away 2012/13

A leading contender for the Gunners' worst ever away strip.

Who knows what was going through the heads of the kit designers as purple and black just aren't Arsenal colours.

Worn in the humiliating League Cup quarter-final defeat against League Two side Bradford City.

Worn by: Nacho Monreal, Francis Coquelin, Gervinho.

Away 2013/14

Nike certainly got Arsenal fans back on their side with their next away kit as yellow made a triumphant return.

It was almost an exact copy of the famous 2003/04 shirt with the only real difference the blue and yellow socks.

It proved to be a big winner.

Worn by: Santi Cazorla, Mathieu Flamini, Yaya Sanogo.

Home 2014/15

The 2014/15 season saw Arsenal in Puma kits with the club signing a big deal after two decades with Nike.

There was to be no blue on their new shirts with the German company electing to go with the club's traditional colours.

However, instead of going with a plain red body, Puma added a bit of white just below the shoulders.

Worn by: Mathieu Debuchy, Gabriel, Calum Chambers.

Away 2014/15

The club's first Puma away kit proved to be a winner as they opted for the classic yellow and blue shirt.

It was a darker blue than the previous away shirt and it featured a bit of red piping down the sides.

Worn by: Mesut Ozil, Alexis Sanchez, Joe Campbell.

Third 2014/15

Arsenal now had three kits for the season after signing up with Puma at the start of the campaign.

Their first third kit was in colours the club have had previously with a navy and light blue number.

Supporters will remember it from the FA Cup win over Manchester United on the way to the club lifting the famous trophy for the second successive year.

Worn by: Hector Bellerin, Kieran Gibbs, Danny Welbeck.

Home 2015/16

Arsenal's next home shirt with Puma featured plenty of white as the sportswear giant made a few alterations.

The new top had a grandad collar with a button and it also featured a tinge of gold.

Worn by: Mohamed Elneny, Alex Iwobi, Chuba Akpom.

Away 2015/16

Gold made a return as Arsenal's secondary colour for the first time since the famous 2001/02 season.

The predominantly gold top with navy sleeves also featured a diamond pattern on the front and reverse.

Worn by: Nacho Monreal, Olivier Giroud, Theo Walcott.

Third 2015/16

Arsenal were once again given a third kit by Puma and it was rather bold.

The navy design came with a striking graphic print on the lower half with gold, white and light blue vertical stripes.

Plenty of fans will remember it from another Champions League defeat in Munich.

Worn by: Per Mertesacker, Santi Cazorla, Jeff Reine-Adelaide.

Home 2016/17

There wasn't an awful lot different from the previous year's kit with Arsenal's new home shirt.

The grandad collar had gone and there was more white on the shoulders, with a dark red vertical stripe running down from the neck to the base of the top.

Worn by: Rob Holding, Granit Xhaka, Lucas Perez.

Away 2016/17

Yellow once again made a return after the previous gold shirt.

However, instead of going with the usual navy blue as Nike had done in previous years, Puma elected to use grey on the sleeves and shorts.

Worn by: Shkodran Mustafi, Jack Wilshere, Aaron Ramsey.

Third 2016/17

Arsenal once again had a navy third kit for the 2016/17 season but this time Puma decided to team it up with fluorescent green.

It was certainly bright given that the sportswear giant chose to go with fluorescent green shorts and socks.

It was the shirt Mesut Ozil wore when he scored his stunning goal against Ludogorets in the Champions League.

Worn by: Theo Walcott, Alex Iwobi, Mesut Ozil.

Third 2017/18

A shirt fans will want to very much forget due to their wretched record when wearing it.

Instead of the usual navy blue that Arsenal tend to go with for an away strip, Puma went with a bright blue third shirt.

It was worn in the 4-0 hammering at Liverpool in August 2017.

Worn by: Konstantinos Mavropanos, Jack Wilshere, Danny Welbeck.

Home 2018/19

Arsenal fans have certainly had plenty to say about the club's final Puma home shirt before the deal with adidas gets underway.

The sportswear giant have once again gone with white shoulders and the red pattern on the sleeves hasn't exactly gone down well.

Worn by: Sokratis, Lucas Torreira, Matteo Guendouzi

Away 2018/19

The tried and tested navy blue shirt made its return again for the club's away kit.

This top features a burgundy strip running horizontally across the middle of the shirt and around the sleeves.

Puma also mixed it up with the shorts as they went with a combination of navy and burgundy.

Worn by: Stephan Lichtsteiner, Carl Jenkinson, Mohamed Elneny.

Third 2018/19

The Gunners were given a turquoise shirt for the first time in the Premier League era by Puma.

Not a colour associated with Arsenal, the bright shirt, which features a shirt collar, also features two navy stripes around the sleeves.

Worn by: Laurent Koscielny, Rob Holding, Emile Smith Rowe.
